case_vignette:
A fullterm newborn African American male is noticed by nursing staff to have multiple dark spots on the head and neck present at birth. The patient was born via spontaneous vaginal delivery and had an unremarkable prenatal course. Examination reveals scattered collarettes of scale on the face and neck and few ovoid hyperpigmented macules scattered on the neck. Remainder of exam was unremarkable. The patient was discharged home with the mother.

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have multiple dark spots on my head and neck that have been present since birth. Additionally, there are areas of flaky skin on my face and neck.
Do these spots change in size or color over time?
No, the spots have not changed in size or color since birth.
Do you have any history of epilepsy or seizures?
No, I do not have a history of epilepsy or seizures.
Do any of your family members have similar skin conditions or any known genetic disorders?
I don't know if any of my family members have similar skin conditions or any known genetic disorders.
Do these dark spots have smooth or rough texture?
The dark spots themselves do not have a rough texture.
Have you noticed any developmental delays or learning difficulties?
No, I haven't noticed any developmental delays or learning difficulties.
Final Diagnosis: Nevus depigmentosus
